specs/train/approved/glance/barbican-sec.message:
glance internally uses cursive library to deal with Barbican. Cursive library doesn't have a public/private method to delete the secret_id [1], so we first need to add below public method to signature_utils module of cursive library.::

def delete_certificate(context, signature_certificate_uuid):
    """Delete the certificate object from the given certificate uuid.

    :param context: the user context for authentication
    :param signature_certificate_uuid: the uuid to use to delete the
                                       certificate
    """
    keymgr_api = key_manager.API()

    try:
        # Delete the certificate
        keymgr_api.delete(context, signature_certificate_uuid)
    except ManagedObjectNotFoundError as e:
        msg = (_LE('Certificate not found with ID %(id)s: %(e)s')
               % {'id': signature_certificate_uuid,
                  'e': encodeutils.exception_to_unicode(e)})
        LOG.error(msg)
    except KeyManagerError as e:
        # The problem encountered may be backend-specific, since castellan
        # can use different backends.  Rather than importing all possible
        # backends here, the generic "Exception" is used.
        msg = (_LE("Unable to retrieve certificate with ID %(id)s: %(e)s")
               % {'id': signature_certificate_uuid,
                  'e': encodeutils.exception_to_unicode(e)})
        LOG.error(msg)

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cursive/blob/master/cursive/signature_utils.py

Or we can use castellan library to create barbican key manager API and use delete method directly in glance, but it will be against the standards of using common libraries IMO.

For example::
from castellan.common.exception import KeyManagerError
from castellan.common.exception import ManagedObjectNotFoundError
from castellan import key_manager 

key_manager = key_manager.API()

and then call key_manager.delete()

In short move delete_certificate method from above comment to glance/common/utils.py instead of adding it to cursive library.

Cinder is currently using the second pattern:
https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/commit/ad9eda63ace9a2dbd39bb6e5d277db6b46cfd066/cinder/volume/utils.py#L941-L962

I think Glance, should, too.  Currently, the cursive library doesn't deal with certificate creation or deletion, it's focused on "OpenStack-specific validation of digital signatures".  Adding a delete_certificate method will change that focus (and will be asymmetric unless you also add a create_certificate method).  I think it makes sense to use the castellan key_manager interface to handle key deletion.

ceph/utils.py.message:
After digging a little bit, it appears the previously committed Nautilus enablement change for the ceph-mon pulls the rug under the ceph-osd charm.

Could it be it pulls the rug under other charms, and should the change be the other way round?

I.e add a new function to check for bootstrap of the mon instead of changing the meaning of a existing function that broke other charms?

well, afaik the only charms that use charms.ceph are ceph-mon, ceph-osd, ceph-radosgw, and ceph-proxy. The latter two (radosgw and proxy) don't use that function at all, leaving us with ceph-mon and ceph-osd that use that function.

I can update the ceph-mon charm in reverse, but I don't think that the _bootstrap_keyring bit is used elsewhere, as it is an OSD specific keyring path as well. An alternate approach would be to _not_ include this part in charms.ceph, but rather migrate this "readiness" check directly into ceph-osd, as it is application specific code, rather than easily sharable code.

nova/conductor/tasks/migrate.py.message: Did you also intend to add checks for nested & sharing providers?
I'd have to dig into how to figure that out, but assume it just means having allocations on more than the compute node resource provider.

I just re-wrote all this code to run through the scheduler, and the first thing that blows up is GET /allocation_candidates with no results because it thinks we're trying to find a spare capacity for the new request, long before we ever get to claim_resources which does the PUT /allocations...so yeah we're kind of in a bind here, tons of chicken and egg code.

1. We have to hit the scheduler before swapping the allocations to the migration so we don't double up.

2. But we still want to claim resources with the max amount between the old/new flavor.

3. And we want to run through the scheduler filters, but also need to filter providers based on things like required/forbidden traits, which is what GET /allocation_candidates is for.

So far in this hacky change, I've done #1 and #2, and I was working on an alternative for #3 but hit the GET /a_c issue.

So we could maybe:

1. Verify required and forbidden traits on the provider by hitting GET /resource_providers?in_tree=<source node uuid>&required=<traits from new flavor> from conductor

2. Then do the PUT /allocations on the max'ed resources like in this change.

3. Then run through select_destinations but with a scheduler hint that will bypass GET /a_c like in the rebuild case:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/fef4696e005b12c2316e652d17d2310d573dd0e7/nova/scheduler/manager.py#L128

Which will enable us to run through the scheduler filters, but not attempt to claim any resources in placement:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/fef4696e005b12c2316e652d17d2310d573dd0e7/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L185

That is duplicating a lot of scheduler logic here in conductor which is nasty and potentially misses any cases we need for GET /a_c like shared or nested providers.

I guess something down the line is munging the flavor into an unnumbered RequestGroup which is breaking with the thing I'm adding which doesn't have any resources.

The request groups from the ports are always numbered. There could be only one unnumbered group. I think this trait belongs that group logically. (And by adding the trait to the flavor.extra_spec you basically make sure that it is added to the unnumbered group.) 
I guess the placement error above is caused by the fact that this new group only has required traits but no requested resources. I think that is not supported by placement.

> I think that is not supported by placement.

That's correct. I wonder if we should "fix" that. Because there may come a day when the compute RP has no resources to give (e.g. CPU/mem in NUMA providers, shared disk) but it's still the thing exposing traits we want to filter by.

I vaguely remember discussions of traits being "inherited" by descendants. We must have decided against it, and I don't remember why, but present me thinks it sounds like a terrible idea.

But how would we express that otherwise? root_required=X,Y,Z? Or simply allow required$N=X,Y,Z where there's no corresponding resources$N, and it means "there must exist a provider in the resulting allocation with these traits"? That's a bastardization of the granular syntax, at least if group_policy=isolate.

For *right now* you could make sure to stuff it in the unnumbered group, but that would mean flavors are *required* to put their VCPU/MEMORY_MB resources in the unnumbered group, which is not something we've restricted previously. And it also goes out the window once we start doing NUMA things, which we're talking about doing for Train.

I've added this boggle to the nova/placement xproj etherpad [1] - unless you think there's an easy way to solve it.

> I vaguely remember discussions of traits being "inherited" by
 > descendants. We must have decided against it, and I don't remember
 > why, but present me thinks it sounds like a terrible idea.

My recollection was that un-numbered required was for the whole true, but numbered was not. I'll go see if I can find where we made that true.

We did make it the case that numbered requireds must be paired with a numbered resource. For the reasons you state, it does seem that the un-numbered required should not need a un-numbered pair.

Matt's original trouble was because he had a numbered required and no numbered resource.
I'm just going to avoid the RequestGroup complexity and have the trait hitch a ride on the RequestSpec.flavor.extra_specs.

Note to self:

ok so this is applied to the compute node RP
so we want to request this in the un numbered request group
not in a separate request group for the volume as we are not looking for a volume with COMPUTE_VOLUME_MULTI_ATTACH we are looking for a compute host.

Probably shouldn't persist it, because let's say you create a server that is not volume backed, but has a non-root data volume attached that is multiattach capable, then you detach that volume later and migrate it, we'd force the scheduler to pick a host that supports multiattach volumes even though the server isn't using one.

there could also be cases that I boot a server and then attached a multi-attach volume, so we still have to calculate if there is a need for multi attach able compute nodes. So I guess the safest way is not persist this and recalculate for multi attach when we doing actions

Although technically we could have the same issue when migrating the server if we don't filter properly...but do we really want to try and recalculate this for every move operation? If we made this more generic with a placement pre-request filter, we'd have to get the multiattach information off the BDMs attached to the instance, which is buried deep in the connection_info for attached volumes and would not exist for BDMs during server create (since they aren't attached yet). I guess we could assume that if you can create a server with a multiattach volume, chances are going to be good that you can migrate with it too.

this seems reasonable, but had you wanted to do it on the request groups, I think what would have been needed, based on the error you pasted before is that you take the request_groups[0] (if present) and extend it's required value, otherwise you add a new request group, which becomes the Nth, creating required1, which is not the thing you want.

That wouldn't fix this because in the test that was failing, requested_resources was empty. The RequestGroup that was added was added by some scheduler utility code that translates the Flavor in the RequestSpec to a RequestGroup, so it does the magic with vcpu/memory_mb/disk_gb for resources and any required traits and that wasn't jiving with the RequestGroup I was adding. I'm not sure why, and I'm not sure if it's a bug or not, but it's definitely a very confusing interface and I didn't want to spend the time trying to grok all of that code to make it work. Hence hitching a ride, man.

this seems like sketchy logic.  If we bump up VSWITCH_MEMORY_MB to 2GB this will fail.

The comment where constants.VSWITCH_MEMORY_MB is defined is this:

# Defines per-socket vswitch memory requirements (in MB)

This (combined with the name of the constant) describes an *amount* of memory, not a page size.  If it's an amount, then it's wrong to compare it against a page size.  If it actually is a page size, then the comment needs to be updated to reflect that and the name of the constant should be changed.
This constant defines the default vswitch size 1G and we don't support size 2G.
i stumbled on this too until I realized what the variable name actually meant 1GB page size.

It is used as the default page size. Using a different constant MIB_1G here to make it more obvious.

helm-toolkit/templates/manifests/_job-bo.message: Do we have the use case in where we need to encode the executable script?

Yes, the use case is the postgresql backup/restore enhancements: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/655231/71/postgresql/templates/job-ks-user.yaml

In this case the keystone user creation shell script is contained in a secret rather than a configMap. This is because Postgresql was recently converted to use Secret for its scripts instead of ConfigMap: https://review.opendev.org/gitweb?p=openstack/openstack-helm-infra.git;a=blob;f=postgresql/templates/configmap-bin.yaml;h=f5c931ea54ebf3ff47982704c90a9cfad9f31911;hb=refs/heads/master

helm-toolkit/templates/manifests/_job-ks.message: should this be 4XX? Does it make sense to have the execute bit set for a secret?

Actually, I researched this, and 444 is not the right value either. https://v1-13.docs.kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/configuration/secret/#using-secrets-as-files-from-a-pod

The defaultValue 0555 when converted to octal becomes: 1053. But the decimal value 365 converts to 555, which I believe is what we want (we DO want the execute bit because it's an executable script).

If the bash script is specified in a configMap, it should also be the same decimal value: 365. See latest patchset for this change.
I think you're right.  Probably should be 444

glance/api/authorization.py.message: It's possible that this could be None (see line 73), which will cause an AttributeError at line 55.  Maybe change line 37 to "if image_repo and CONF.enabled_backends:" ?

I may be thinking about this the wrong way, so I'll explain my problem and you can tell me what I'm missing.

Suppose an operator has enabled_backends configured like in our unit tests:
enabled_backends = fast:file, cheap:file, read_only:http

A new image gets added, so it will have a location with the correct metadata
{'id': '5e714993-559c-4839-ab17-e3711c851bd9', 'url': 'file:///tmp/tmpvljwt2p1/a85abd86-55b3-4d5b-b0b4-5d0a6e6042fc', 'metadata': {'backend': 'fast'}, 'status': 'active'}

We do an image-list call.  The lazy update grabs the location and calls store_utils.get_store_id_from_uri(loc['url']).  It gets 'cheap' because that comes first in the map.  This is different from the store_id in the location metadata, so it logs a warning and updates the metadata -- which is now incorrect.

I need you to explain why that can't happen.

Hi Brian,
This will not happen because, fast and cheap will have different file paths.
For example fast will have path as file:///tmp/tmp_fast and cheap will have path as file:///tmp/tmp_cheap.

If you look at the method from store_utils, then it is checking the location url is starts with store.url_prefix in this case it will return True only for fast and not cheap.

Let me know whether this satisfies your doubt.

I have same problem here as in the glance_store patch.

Why warning? Isn't this something we expect to happen and is not something operator should take action on? This will potentially dump thousands of warnings into the logs on something that is normal operation and expected making it even worse than it happening when updating locations in glance_store.

IMHO this should be debut or at max info, unless we have strong case why every single one of these should be highlighted to the operator.

glance/common/store_utils.py.message: Here the warning is very much appropriate.

just curious why we aren't logging here -- this seems very similar to the situation at line 166.  Here a location URL is using a scheme that's not in enabled_backends, whereas at line 166 it's a registered scheme, but it doesn't correspond to any of the stores listed in enabled_backends.

Check with Sean (he knows this better than I do), but instead of passing in a string and a dict, you're passing in a single argument (a tuple of string and dict).  I don't think it will break anything, but the log message may not be formatted correctly.  I think you may need to unpack the tuple by passing in *reason, or separate the reason from the data dict and pass them in as separate arguments.  Or maybe oslo_logging is smart enough to handle this properly.
You are correct Brian, this will not work as expected. Get rid of the reason variable and just move the string and formatting args into the LOG.warning() call as-is and it will be good.

I think on this one, you want reason = _("string") and then LOG.warning(reason, uri) so that the new string won't be created unless the logger needs it.  Or you can just do LOG.warning(_("Invalid location uri %s", uri)

Feel free to push back on this, I've been bad about ignoring unnecessary string creation in my own code, and I'm trying to get better about it, and i may be seeing problems where none exist.

Warning messages should not be translated with _(). And log messages should not be formatted. Get rid of the reason variable, move things into the LOG.warning call, and change '%' to ',' so the formatting values are passed in as args to the logger so it can translate when needed.

You missed Sean's comment about not translating log messages.  The current thinking is that all log messages should be untranslated so that operators will get better search engine results.  Only user-facing messages (e.g., exceptions) are translated now. [0]

Also need to fix this on line 157.

[0] https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.i18n/latest/user/guidelines.html

I'm fixing the same issue https://review.opendev.org/#/c/672666 by another LP, need to align with you first. Comments in my patch said the retry should implemented in the thread, what's your idea?
Seems like unnecessary complexity to track which ones have been downloaded in sysinv

Brent's feedback on Patchset 1 was:

"Why do we need to keep a list of failed downloads vs just downloading everything. If it is already there then it is basically a noop." 

and the suggestion was to restart the entire batch of downloads. This means downloads are retried at the highest level, not in each thread.

Why do you need to restart the entire download when potentially there could be one hiccup in one of the batches/the last batch?

It's not noop. Even if the image is already in the local cache, it still makes the request to verify what it already has matches with the image at source.

Ugh. Hate to do this, but maybe it would be better to throw the guts of this loop in a function and use the retry decorator from sysinv/common/retrying.py. There are example of using it in agent/manager.py and conductor/manager.py

Doing this would hurt readability because:
- same exception is raised on operation abort and download fail
- would need to create another helper function for the retry decorator to handle inner loop exception based on "reason" field

Usage of "for ... else" is a consequence of a previous review  requirement that we don't track failed images so I tried to keep the number of variables used in this context as low as possible.

The reversed(range(...)) is just a trick to skip sleeping after last download attempt (there's also a comment) so I don't need to compare idx with MAX_DOWNLOAD_ATTEMPTS-1.
I can live with this as we want to get this functionality in. We can look to optimize in the future.
I'm thinking recovery_attempts makes more sense here as this would indicate a number vs. a boolean?

The commit message says that when downloading images collect the list of failed downloads and retry the download, but from the code, looks like it doesn't wait for all images to be iterated then start retry but exits and retries once there is an image failed. Is it intended? My concern is in this way not all images have 3 chances to retry. 

ie.. image 1,2,3,4

first round to download
1 succeed 
2 failed
then 3, 4 will have only 2 chances.

second round to download
1 succeed
2 succeed
3 failed
then 4 will have only 1 chance
Done. Updated commit message. Initial proposal was retrying to download only failed images but it was decided to retry the entire batch.

this is a **really** cool feature - does it fix bytes in the listing as well!?

I debated about also adding a X-Symlink-Target-Size and shoving symlink_size into listings... but my gut reaction would've been to make all of these requirements orthogonal, so you could have

- symlink with no etag/size restrictions
- symlink with just etag restriction
- symlink with both etag & size restrictions
- symlink with just size restriction

and that last one felt weird to me. "If you do a GET here, I'll go give you this other object, but only if it's exactly N bytes." seems kinda arbitrary -- it makes more sense if there's *also* and etag restriction... but it *also* seemed weird to make the size requirement only be valid if there's an etag requirement... so I just punted that part of the listing problem to versioned_writes in the next patch in the chain.

Is this a reasonable response status? It's not really a client error... and to the degree that it *is*, 412 is kinda misleading... the client didn't (necessarily) include any If-Match/If-None-Match/If-Modified-Since/If-Unmodified-Since headers...

But then, we abuse the hell out of 412 *already*, using it for things like "this path isn't UTF-8"...

Maybe 409 Conflict would be better, though? That'd match what you get from a busted SLO...

No, it's actually really well-defined: https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.20.0/test/functional/test_versioned_writes.py#L640-L757

This addition is to counteract the removal of https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.20.0/swift/common/middleware/symlink.py#L511 -- I did it because if I'm going to make versioned_writes know the ins and outs of symlinks *anyway*, I ought to at least get symlinks out of the business of knowing how versioned_writes works.

Just a question: What are all possible state values of onboardingState, operationalState and usageState, for all different cases(i.e. before post-condition, error and susses of completion)?
And NFV-SOL 005 Figure B.2.2-1 describes all state values and their transition model. I added a reference to it.

onBoardingState:
  CREATED: The VNF package resource has been created.
  UPLOADING: The associated VNF package content is being uploaded.
  PROCESSING: The associated VNF package content is being processed, e.g. validation.
  ONBOARDED: The associated VNF package content is successfully on-boarded.

operationalState
  ENABLED: The VNF package is enabled, i.e. it can be used for instantiation of new VNF instances.
  DISABLED: The VNF package is disabled, i.e. it cannot be used for further VNF instantiation requests (unless   and until the VNF package is re-enabled).

usageState:
  IN_USE: VNF instances instantiated from this VNF package exist.
  NOT_IN_USE: No existing VNF instance is instantiated from this VNF package.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: My thinking is that this patch didn't change the behavior. paunch's behavior up to date was that it runs a set of commands for a set of containers and only logs the errors - see my previous comment (base.py:134).
It validates volumes in docker and logs the error in the same way podman would behave in this case.

Doing that would change the behavior between docker and podman. In case of docker, we would raise and stop iterating over other containers, in case of podman, we would only log the error about not existing directories (in base.py:135) and continue executing other containers.
There is logging in the validation code with the level of error.
https://github.com/openstack/paunch/blob/master/paunch/builder/compose1.py#L125-L128

paunch/builder/base.py.message: I think you should raise an exception like SystemError('...'). In that way it'd log the error and return an exception message.

we should modify this one to apply the action filters over the running containers only.

That would save us a 2nd 'podman ps' call, so we could figure out, if exec would work earlier

I think I misidentified the place where we have the 1st podman ps -a call.

It is likely current_config_ids() and containers_in_config() calls that need to be extended to support the look among running only flag and custom filters.

This variable is only used to indicate if the (currently one) validation passed, nothing more or less. I added doc strings in the *_exec_args and *_run_args methods, so you would also want to change those if you want to change the name or propose a new structure.

You need to raise a proper exception here. CI is failing with:
"exceptions must be old-style classes or derived from BaseException, not NoneType
(https://logs.opendev.org/94/675494/2/check/tripleo-ci-centos-7-containers-multinode/40323bc/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/undercloud_install.log.txt.gz#_2019-08-09_00_18_40)
I disagree here, if a container fails for whatever reason, we should not continue with other containers and fail as early as possible.

The raise keyword is used for re-raising an exception after you caught it and you don't want the stack trace to include this line. I don't see why it's used here...

Also, are you sure you want to throw an exception? This code is iterating on a set of containers and an error in one shouldn't impact others, that's why the "continue" keyword is originally used.
Maybe we don't want to check if the container is running, but return an exception at this point?
I don't see the point of running an exception after the exec (L126). Failing earlier would I think be better in the case of a container not running just before the exec.

paunch/runner.py.message: This block looks correct to me.

As I noted earlier, let's move this ps / ps -a + custom --filter values into current_config_ids() and containers_in_config() methods. That saves the 2nd call for the podman ps executed in this redundant place.

nova/tests/unit/virt/hyperv/test_hostops.message:
> I know.

Yup, that review comment was for myself/other reviewers :)

I know. The reason I've done this is because it would fail otherwise. The return value is used in an if:

    if self._hostutils.is_cpu_feature_present(fkey):

that if is basically a __nonzero__ call. The failure looks like this:

    Expected: [call(3),
     ...
     call(21)]
    Actual: [call(3),
     call().__nonzero__(),
     ...
     call(21),
     call().__nonzero__()]
